subPoints: docstring - providing context; stating what the function does
docstring - clearly defining all input variables/objects
docstring - clearly defining the returned object(s)
internal check - proper use of 'if not isinstance', 'raise' statements, etc.
isolating ideas to user-defined functions
optional parameters - nice idea to include them
type hinting - applied well for input variables (and what for what is returned, if applicable)
type hinting - good use of typing library

neutral.mainPoint: Okay user-defined function(s), but the following could be improved
subPoints: assert vs. raise - it is better to use 'raise' since 'assert' can be bypassed
complex - a bit too many ideas placed into a single function
Your solution did not include user-defined functions to isolate concepts, improves reusability, transferability and debugging
You missed an obvious situation to crete a user-defined function that would have made your code more concise.

negative.mainPoint: Your user-defined functions had the following problems
subPoints: complex - too many ideas place in a single function, which limits reusability, transferability and debugging
documentation - used comments instead of docstrings to provide context and usage for a function
docstring - none provided for specifying context and usage
docstring - no statement about what the function does
docstring - no statement about what the input variables are
docstring - no statement about what the function returns
docstring - units should be specified for the input and out put variables/objects
global variables - use local variable in your function (e.g., improves transferability)
internal checks - none provided (e.g., 'if not isinstance')
internal checks - the check logic is overly complicated or too dense and should be separated for readability.
structure - main code logic should be nested under the internal checks (e.g., within an else statement) for proper flow control
trivial function - does very little, and arguably does not warrant being a function
type hinting - none provided
type hinting - incorrect type(s)
keyword arguments calls - include the parameter that are being assigned the argument to (e.g., 'my_function(param1=arg1, param2=arg2)'. Doing so ensure that the arguments are passed correctly.
